objectives: Use the correct punctuation for each sentence type
Create sentences of different structures for better communication

sections.text: Sentences are groups of words that tell a complete idea. Not all sentences do the same work. Some tell us something, some ask something, some give an order, and some show strong feelings. Knowing different sentence types helps us speak and write clearly and correctly. There are mainly four types of sentences: Declarative, Interrogative, Imperative, and Exclamatory.

examples.label: Tells something
examples.value: The village is quiet at night.

examples.label: Asks something
examples.value: Do you know the way to the market?

examples.label: Gives an order
examples.value: Finish your work quickly.

examples.label: Shows strong feeling
examples.value: How delicious this mango is!

examples.label: Tells a fact
examples.value: Cows eat grass.

examples.label: Asks for information
examples.value: What time is the bus?

examples.label: Requests something
examples.value: Please help me lift this sack.

examples.label: Expresses surprise
examples.value: Wow, look at the size of that pumpkin!

examples.label: States an opinion
examples.value: I find morning walks very refreshing.

examples.label: Seeks confirmation
examples.value: Have you seen my cow?

examples.label: Gives advice
examples.value: You should drink clean water.

examples.label: Expresses joy
examples.value: What a wonderful surprise!

examples.label: Gives instruction
examples.value: Plant the seeds in a straight line.

examples.label: States a general truth
examples.value: Plants need sunlight to grow.

examples.label: Asks about choice
examples.value: Would you like tea or coffee?

sections.text: A declarative sentence is the most common type of sentence. It simply makes a statement, tells a fact, or gives an opinion. It always ends with a full stop (.). It declares something to be true or tells a piece of information. They are used for everyday conversation and sharing facts.

sections.text: An interrogative sentence asks a question. It always ends with a question mark (?). We use them when we want to get information or when we want to know something. There are two main types: Yes/No questions and Wh-questions.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: Are you going to the market?

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: Is this your pen?

examples.label: Wh-Question (What)
examples.value: What are you cooking for dinner?

examples.label: Wh-Question (Where)
examples.value: Where did you put the sickle?

examples.label: Wh-Question (When)
examples.value: When does the school start?

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: Have you finished your chores?

examples.label: Wh-Question (Who)

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: Will you come to my house tomorrow?

examples.label: Wh-Question (Why)

sections.text: An imperative sentence gives a command, makes a request, or offers advice or instructions. The subject 'you' is usually understood but not said. It can end with a full stop (.) or sometimes an exclamation mark (!) if the command is very strong. These sentences are direct and tell someone to do something.

examples.label: Command
examples.value: Finish your homework before you play.

examples.label: Request
examples.value: Please pass the salt.

examples.label: Instruction
examples.value: Take this medicine after your meal.

examples.label: Advice
examples.value: Work hard if you want to succeed.

examples.label: Command

examples.label: Prohibition (negative command)

examples.label: Instruction

examples.label: Request

examples.label: Command (strong)

examples.label: Instruction

examples.label: Prohibition

sections.text: An exclamatory sentence expresses strong emotion or surprise. It can show joy, anger, fear, excitement, or sadness. It always ends with an exclamation mark (!). These sentences are used to show how someone feels strongly about something. They make your speaking and writing more lively.

examples.value: What a lovely song!

examples.label: Excitement
